<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Peanut skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Peanut</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-semi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-semi (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-semi</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
</p>
<div class="dablink">"Goober peas" redirects here. For the folk song, see <a href="/w/index.php?title=Goober_Peas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Goober Peas (page does not exist)">Goober Peas</a>.</div><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Main_other&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Main other (page does not exist)">Template:Main other</a>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Globalize/US&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Globalize/US (page does not exist)">Template:Globalize/US</a>
</p>
<div><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Taxobox/core&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Taxobox/core (page does not exist)">Template:Taxobox/core</a></div>
<p>The <b>peanut</b>, or <b>groundnut</b> (<i>Arachis hypogaea</i>), is a species in the <a href="/wiki/Legume" title="Legume">legume</a> or "bean" <a href="/wiki/Family_(biology)" title="Family (biology)">family</a> (<a href="/wiki/Fabaceae" title="Fabaceae">Fabaceae</a>). The peanut was probably first domesticated and cultivated in the valleys of <a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay">Paraguay</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> It is an <a href="/wiki/Annual_plant" title="Annual plant">annual</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Herbaceous&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Herbaceous (page does not exist)">herbaceous</a> plant growing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> tall. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Leaf&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Leaf (page does not exist)">leaves</a> are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Opposite_leaves&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Opposite leaves (page does not exist)">opposite</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pinnate" title="Pinnate">pinnate</a> with four leaflets (two opposite pairs; no terminal leaflet); each leaflet is 1 to 7&#160;cm (⅜ to 2¾ in) long and 1 to 3&#160;cm (⅜ to 1&#160;inch) across.
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Flower&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Flower (page does not exist)">flowers</a> are a typical peaflower in shape, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> (¾ to 1½ in) across, yellow with reddish veining.  The specific name, <i>hypogaea</i> means "under the earth"; after <a href="/wiki/Pollination" title="Pollination">pollination</a>, the flower stalk elongates, causing it to bend until the ovary touches the ground. Continued stalk growth then pushes the ovary underground where the mature <a href="/wiki/Fruit" title="Fruit">fruit</a> develops into a <a href="/wiki/Legume" title="Legume">legume</a> pod, the peanut&#160;– a classical example of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Geocarpy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Geocarpy (page does not exist)">geocarpy</a>. Pods are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> long, containing 1 to 4 <a href="/wiki/Seed" title="Seed">seeds</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p><p>Peanuts are known by many other local names such as <b>earthnuts</b>, <b>ground nuts</b>, <b>goober peas</b>, <b>monkey nuts</b>, <b>pygmy nuts</b> and <b>pig nuts.</b><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> Despite its name and appearance, the peanut is not a <a href="/wiki/Nut_(fruit)#Botanical_definition" title="Nut (fruit)">nut</a>, but rather a <a href="/wiki/Legume" title="Legume">legume</a>.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:TOC_limit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:TOC limit (page does not exist)">Template:TOC limit</a>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p>The domesticated peanut is an <a href="/wiki/Amphidiploid" title="Amphidiploid" class="mw-redirect">amphidiploid</a> or <a href="/wiki/Allotetraploid" title="Allotetraploid" class="mw-redirect">allotetraploid</a>, meaning that it has two sets of chromosomes from two different species, thought to be <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=A._duranensis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A. duranensis (page does not exist)">A. duranensis</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=A._ipaensis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A. ipaensis (page does not exist)">A. ipaensis</a></i>. These likely combined in the wild to form the <a href="/wiki/Tetraploid" title="Tetraploid" class="mw-redirect">tetraploid</a> species <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arachis_monticola&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arachis monticola (page does not exist)">A. monticola</a></i>, which gave rise to the domesticated peanut.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup> This domestication might have taken place in <a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay">Paraguay</a> or <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a>, where the wildest strains grow today. Many <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pre-Columbian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pre-Columbian (page does not exist)">pre-Columbian</a> cultures, such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Moche_(culture)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Moche (culture) (page does not exist)">Moche</a>, depicted peanuts in their art.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>Archeologists have dated the oldest specimens to about 7,600 years, found in <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> Cultivation spread as far as Mesoamerica, where the Spanish conquistadors found the <i>tlalcacahuatl</i> (the plant's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nahuatl&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nahuatl (page does not exist)">Nahuatl</a> name, whence <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Spanish" title="Mexican Spanish">Mexican Spanish</a> <i>cacahuate</i> and French <i>cacahuète</i>) being offered for sale in the marketplace of <a href="/wiki/Tenochtitlan" title="Tenochtitlan">Tenochtitlan</a> (Mexico City). The plant was later spread worldwide by European traders.
</p><p>Although the peanut was mainly a garden crop for much of the <a href="/wiki/Colonial_history_of_the_United_States" title="Colonial history of the United States">colonial period</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Colonial_North_America&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Colonial North America (page does not exist)">North America</a>, it was mostly used as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Animal_feed&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Animal feed (page does not exist)">animal feed</a> stock until the 1930s.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> In the United States, a US Department of Agriculture program (see <a href="#U.S._Department_of_Agriculture_.28USDA.29_program">below</a>) to encourage agricultural production and human consumption of peanuts was instituted in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.  <a href="/wiki/George_Washington_Carver" title="George Washington Carver">George Washington Carver</a> is well known for his participation in that program in which he developed hundreds of recipes for peanuts.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Cultivation">Cultivation</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Peanut_stalks.jpg" title="File:Peanut stalks.jpg">File:Peanut stalks.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Peanut stalks just after the fall of the flowers. What remains of the flower is crimson-colored, and cone-shaped to dig the ground better. The ovary is whitish and already thicker than the stalk.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Arachis_hypogaea_006.JPG" title="File:Arachis hypogaea 006.JPG">File:Arachis hypogaea 006.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Pollinated Peanut pod stalks shoots which will grow into the soil, where the tip of the shoot will become a peanut. The shoot on the left of the image has already entered the soil.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Peanut_harvester.JPG" title="File:Peanut harvester.JPG">File:Peanut harvester.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Track-type peanut harvester.</div></div></div>
<p>The orange-veined, yellow-petaled, pea-like flower of the <i>Arachis hypogaea</i> is borne in axillary clusters above ground.  Following <a href="/wiki/Self-pollination" title="Self-pollination">self-pollination</a>, the flowers fade and wither. The stalk at the base of the ovary, called the pedicel, elongates rapidly, and turns downward to bury the fruits several inches in the ground, where they complete their development. The entire plant, including most of the roots, is removed from the soil during harvesting.<sup id="cite_ref-PCA_Harvesting_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PCA_Harvesting-8">[8]</a></sup> The fruits have wrinkled shells that are constricted between pairs of the one to four (usually two) seeds per pod.
</p><p>Peanuts grow best in light, sandy <a href="/wiki/Loam" title="Loam">loam</a> soil. They require five months of warm weather, and an annual rainfall of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> or the equivalent in <a href="/wiki/Irrigation" title="Irrigation">irrigation</a> water.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p><p>The pods ripen 120 to 150 days after the seeds are planted. If the crop is harvested too early, the pods will be unripe. If they are harvested late, the pods will snap off at the stalk, and will remain in the soil.<sup id="cite_ref-PCA_Harvesting_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PCA_Harvesting-8">[8]</a></sup> They need an acidic soil to grow preferably with 5.9-7 pH.
</p><p>Peanuts are particularly susceptible to contamination during growth and storage. Poor storage of peanuts can lead to an infection by the <a href="/wiki/Mold" title="Mold">mold</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fungus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fungus (page does not exist)">fungus</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Aspergillus_flavus" title="Aspergillus flavus">Aspergillus flavus</a></i>, releasing the <a href="/wiki/Toxicity" title="Toxicity">toxic</a> and highly <a href="/wiki/Carcinogen" title="Carcinogen">carcinogenic</a> substance <a href="/wiki/Aflatoxin" title="Aflatoxin">aflatoxin</a>. The aflatoxin-producing molds exist throughout the peanut growing areas and may produce aflatoxin in peanuts when conditions are favorable to fungal growth.
</p><p>Harvesting occurs in two stages{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}: In mechanized systems, a machine is used to cut off the main root of the peanut plant by cutting through the soil just below the level of the peanut pods. The machine lifts the "bush" from the ground and shakes it, then inverts the bush, leaving the plant upside down on the ground to keep the peanuts out of the soil. This allows the peanuts to dry slowly to a bit less than a third of their original moisture level over a period of three to four days. Traditionally, peanuts were pulled and inverted by hand.
</p><p>After the peanuts have dried sufficiently, they are <a href="/wiki/Threshing" title="Threshing">threshed</a>, removing the peanut pods from the rest of the bush.<sup id="cite_ref-PCA_Harvesting_8-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PCA_Harvesting-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cultivation_in_China">Cultivation in China</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Jiangxia-peanuts-harvested-9700.jpg" title="File:Jiangxia-peanuts-harvested-9700.jpg">File:Jiangxia-peanuts-harvested-9700.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Recently harvested peanut plants stacked by a village house near <a href="/wiki/Wuhan" title="Wuhan">Wuhan</a></div></div></div>
<p>The peanut was introduced to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Agriculture_in_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Agriculture in China (page does not exist)">China</a> by Portuguese traders in the 17th century and another variety by American missionaries in the 19th century.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>They became popular and are featured in many Chinese dishes, often being boiled. During the 1980s, peanut production began to increase so greatly that as of 2006, China was the world's largest peanut producer. A major factor in this increase was the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Household-responsibility_system&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Household-responsibility system (page does not exist)">household-responsibility system</a>, which moved financial control from the government to the farmers.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Production">Production</span></h3>
<p>China leads in production of peanuts, having a share of about 41.5% of overall world production, followed by India (18.2%) and the United States of America (6.8%).
In <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>, the leading producer is <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">Greece</a>, at roughly 2000 tons per year. {{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="padding:2px;; border-spacing:0;width:38em;">

<caption> Top ten producers of peanuts in 2008/2009
</caption>
<tr>
<th> Country
</th>

</p>
</th></tr>

</td></tr>

</td></tr>
<tr>

</td></tr>

</td>

</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="font-size: 0.7em;">
<p>Source: <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.fas.usda.gov/psdonline/psdreport.aspx?hidReportRetrievalName=BVS&amp;hidReportRetrievalID=918&amp;hidReportRetrievalTemplateID=1#ancor">USDA Foreign Agricultural Service: Table 13 Peanut Area, Yield, and Production</a>
</p>
</td></tr></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Cultivars_in_the_United_States">Cultivars in the United States</span></h2>
<p>{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Unreferenced section |date=__DATE__ |$B=
{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Unreferenced |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Ambox&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Ambox (page does not exist)">Template:Ambox</a>
}}
}}
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:D0676_peanut_flower.JPG" title="File:D0676 peanut flower.JPG">File:D0676 peanut flower.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Peanut flower</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Arachis_hypogaea_Flower.jpg" title="File:Arachis hypogaea Flower.jpg">File:Arachis hypogaea Flower.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i>Arachis hypogaea</i> Flower</div></div></div>
<p>Thousands of peanut <a href="/wiki/Cultivar" title="Cultivar">cultivars</a> are grown, with four major cultivar groups being the most popular: Spanish, Runner, Virginia, and Valencia. There are also Tennessee red and white groups.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} Certain cultivar groups are preferred for particular uses because of differences in flavor, oil content, size, shape, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_peanut_diseases&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of peanut diseases (page does not exist)">disease</a> resistance. For many uses, the different cultivars are interchangeable. Most peanuts marketed in the shell are of the Virginia type, along with some Valencias selected for large size and the attractive appearance of the shell. Spanish peanuts are used mostly for peanut candy, salted nuts, and <a href="/wiki/Peanut_butter" title="Peanut butter">peanut butter</a>. Most Runners are used to make peanut butter.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Peanut_9417.jpg" title="File:Peanut 9417.jpg">File:Peanut 9417.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Peanut leaves and freshly dug pods</div></div></div>
<p>The various types are distinguished by branching habit and branch length. There are numerous varieties of each type of peanut. There are two main growth forms, bunch and runner. Bunch types grow upright, while runner types grow near the ground.
</p><p>Each year, new cultivars of peanuts are bred and introduced. Introducing a new cultivar may mean changes in the planting rate, adjusting the planter, harvester, dryer, cleaner, sheller, and the method of marketing.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Spanish_group">Spanish group</span></h3>
<p>The small Spanish types are grown in South Africa, and in the southwestern and southeastern US. Prior to 1940, 90% of the peanuts grown in <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(U.S._state)" title="Georgia (U.S. state)">Georgia, USA</a>, were Spanish types, but the trend since then has been larger-seeded, higher-yielding, more <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_peanut_diseases&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of peanut diseases (page does not exist)">disease</a>-resistant cultivars. Spanish peanuts have a higher oil content than other types of peanuts, and in the US are now primarily grown in <a href="/wiki/New_Mexico" title="New Mexico">New Mexico</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oklahoma" title="Oklahoma">Oklahoma</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Texas" title="Texas">Texas</a>.
</p><p>Cultivars of the Spanish group include ‘Dixie Spanish’, ‘Improved Spanish 2B’, ‘GFA Spanish’, ‘Argentine’, ‘Spantex’, ‘Spanette’, ‘Shaffers Spanish’, ‘Natal Common (Spanish)’, "White Kernel Varieties’, ‘Starr’, ‘Comet’, ‘Florispan’, ‘Spanhoma’, ‘Spancross’, ‘OLin’, ‘Tamspan 90’, ‘AT 9899–14’, ‘Spanco’, ‘Wilco I’, ‘GG 2’, ‘GG 4’, ‘TMV 2’, and ‘Tamnut 06’.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Runner_group">Runner group</span></h3>
<p>Since 1940, the southeastern US region has seen a shift to production of Runner group peanuts. This shift is due to good flavor, better roasting characteristics and higher yields when compared to Spanish types, leading to food manufacturers' preference for the use in peanut butter and salted nuts. Georgia's production is now almost 100% Runner type.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>Cultivars of Runners include ‘Southeastern Runner 56-15’, ‘Dixie Runner’, ‘Early Runner’, ‘Virginia Bunch 67’, ‘Bradford Runner’, ‘Egyptian Giant’ (also known as ‘Virginia Bunch’ and ‘Giant’), ‘Rhodesian Spanish Bunch’ (Valencia and Virginia Bunch), ‘North Carolina Runner 56-15’, ‘Florunner’, ‘Virugard’, ‘Georgia Green’, ‘Tamrun 96’, ‘Flavor Runner 458’, ‘Tamrun OL01’, ‘Tamrun OL02’ ‘AT-120’, ‘Andru-93’, ‘Southern Runner’, ‘AT1-1’, ‘Georgia Brown’, ‘GK-7’,and ‘AT-108’.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Virginia_group">Virginia group</span></h3>
<p>The large seeded Virginia group peanuts are grown in the US states of Virginia, North Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, New Mexico, Oklahoma, and parts of Georgia. They are increasing in popularity due to demand for large peanuts for processing, particularly for salting, confections, and roasting in the shells.
</p><p>Virginia group peanuts are either bunch or running in growth habit. The bunch type is upright to spreading. It attains a height of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, and a spread of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> rows that seldom cover the ground. The pods are borne within 5 to 10&#160;cm of the base of the plant.
</p><p>Cultivars of Virginia type peanuts include ‘NC 7’, ‘NC 9’, ‘NC 10C’, ‘NC-V 11’, ‘VA 93B’, ‘NC 12C’, ‘VA-C 92R’, ‘Gregory’, ‘VA 98R’, ‘Perry’, ‘Wilson, ‘Hull’, ’AT VC-2’ and’ Shulamit’
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Valencia_group">Valencia group</span></h3>
<p>Valencia group peanuts are coarse, and they have heavy reddish stems and large foliage. In the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a>, large commercial production is primarily in the <a href="/wiki/South_Plains" title="South Plains">South Plains</a> of <a href="/wiki/West_Texas" title="West Texas">West Texas</a> and eastern <a href="/wiki/New_Mexico" title="New Mexico">New Mexico</a> near and south of Portales, New Mexico, but they are grown on a small scale elsewhere in the South as the best-flavored and preferred type for <a href="/wiki/Boiled_peanuts" title="Boiled peanuts">boiled peanuts</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:By_whom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:By whom (page does not exist)">Template:By whom</a>. They are comparatively tall, having a height of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> and a spread of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. Peanut pods are borne on pegs arising from the main stem and the side branches. Most of the pods are clustered around the base of the plant, and only a few are found several inches away. Valencia types are three- to five-seeded and smooth, with no constriction of the shell between the seeds. Seeds are oval and tightly crowded into the pods. Typical seed weight is 0.4 to 0.5&#160;g.  This type is used heavily for sale roasted and salted in-shell peanuts and <a href="/wiki/Peanut_butter" title="Peanut butter">peanut butter</a>. Varieties include 'Valencia A' and 'Valencia C'.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tennessee_Red_and_Tennessee_White_groups">Tennessee Red and Tennessee White groups</span></h3>
<p>These are alike, except for the color of the seed. Sometimes known also as Texas Red or White, the plants are similar to Valencia types, except the stems are green to greenish brown, and the pods are rough, irregular, and have a smaller proportion of kernels.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Uses">Uses</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Varied_applications">Varied applications</span></h3>
<p>{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Unreferenced section |date=__DATE__ |$B=
{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Unreferenced |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Ambox&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Ambox (page does not exist)">Template:Ambox</a>
}}
}}
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Peanuts_with_skin.jpg" title="File:Peanuts with skin.jpg">File:Peanuts with skin.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Shelled peanuts with skin</div></div></div>
<p>Peanuts have many uses. They can be eaten raw, used in recipes, made into solvents and <a href="/wiki/Peanut_oil" title="Peanut oil">oils</a>, medicines, textile materials, and peanut butter, as well as many other uses. Popular confections made from peanuts include salted peanuts, <a href="/wiki/Peanut_butter" title="Peanut butter">peanut butter</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Peanut_butter_and_jelly_sandwich&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peanut butter and jelly sandwich (page does not exist)">sandwiches</a>, peanut <a href="/w/index.php?title=Candy_bar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Candy bar (page does not exist)">candy bars</a>, peanut butter <a href="/wiki/Cookie" title="Cookie">cookies</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Peanut_butter_cup" title="Peanut butter cup">cups</a>), <a href="/wiki/Peanut_brittle" title="Peanut brittle" class="mw-redirect">peanut brittle</a>, and shelled nuts (plain/roasted).  Salted peanuts are usually roasted in oil and packed in retail-size plastic bags or hermetically sealed cans. Dry roasted salted peanuts are also marketed in significant quantities. Peanuts are often a major ingredient in mixed nuts because of their relative cost compared to Brazil nuts, cashews, walnuts, and so on. Although peanut butter has been a tradition on camping trips and the like because of its high protein content and because it resists spoiling for long periods of time, the primary use of peanut butter is in the home. Large quantities are also used in the commercial manufacture of sandwiches, candy, and bakery products. <a href="/wiki/Boiled_peanuts" title="Boiled peanuts">Boiled peanuts</a> are a preparation of raw, unshelled green peanuts boiled in <a href="/wiki/Brine" title="Brine">brine</a> and often eaten as a snack. More recently, fried peanut recipes have emerged&#160;– allowing both shell and nut to be eaten. Peanuts are also used in a wide variety of other areas, such as <a href="/wiki/Cosmetics" title="Cosmetics">cosmetics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nitroglycerin" title="Nitroglycerin">nitroglycerin</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plastic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plastic (page does not exist)">plastics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dye" title="Dye">dyes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paint" title="Paint">paints</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Peanut_oil">Peanut oil</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Peanut_oil" title="Peanut oil">Peanut oil</a> is often used in cooking, because it has a mild flavor and a relatively high <a href="/w/index.php?title=Smoke_point&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Smoke point (page does not exist)">smoke point</a>. Due to its high monounsaturated content, it is considered more healthy than saturated oils, and is resistant to rancidity. There are several types of peanut oil including: aromatic roasted peanut oil, refined peanut oil, extra virgin or cold pressed peanut oil and peanut extract. In the United States, refined peanut oil is exempt from allergen labeling laws.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Peanut_flour">Peanut flour</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peanut_flour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peanut flour (page does not exist)">Peanut flour</a> is lower in fat than peanut butter, and is popular with chefs because its high protein content makes it suitable as a flavor enhancer.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} Peanut flour is used as a gluten-free solution.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:To_what&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:To what (page does not exist)">Template:To what</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Boiled_peanuts">Boiled peanuts</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Boiled_peanuts" title="Boiled peanuts">Boiled peanuts</a> are a popular snack in the southern United States, as well as in India, China and West Africa.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dry_roasted_peanuts">Dry roasted peanuts</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Peanutjar.jpg" title="File:Peanutjar.jpg">File:Peanutjar.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Roasted peanuts as snack food</div></div></div>
<p>Dry peanuts can be roasted in the shell or shelled in a home oven if spread out one layer deep in a pan and baked at a temperature of 350°F or 177°C for 15 to 20 min (shelled) and 20 to 25 min (in shell).<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> 
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<p>{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Unreferenced section |date=__DATE__ |$B=
{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Unreferenced |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Ambox&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Ambox (page does not exist)">Template:Ambox</a>
}}
}}
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="South_America">South America</span></h4>
<p>Peanuts are used in many sauces for South American meat dishes, especially <a href="/wiki/Rabbit" title="Rabbit">rabbit</a>. Peanuts are common in Peruvian cuisine, which marries native and European ingredients.  For instance, roasted peanuts and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Capsicum_baccatum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Capsicum baccatum (page does not exist)">hot peppers</a>, both native to South America, appear with roasted onions, garlic, and oil—all of European origin—in a smooth sauce poured over boiled potatoes, a dish well known in the city <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arequipa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arequipa (page does not exist)">Arequipa</a> and called <i>papas con ocopa</i>. Another example is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fricassee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fricassee (page does not exist)">fricassee</a> combining a similar mixture with sautéed seafood or boiled and shredded chicken. These dishes are generally known as <i>ajíes</i>, meaning "hot peppers", such as <i>ají de pollo</i> and <i>ají de mariscos</i>. (Seafood <i>ajíes</i> may omit peanuts.)
</p><p>Likewise, during Colonial times, the Spanish in Peru used peanuts to replace nuts unavailable in Peru but used extensively in <a href="/wiki/Spanish_cuisine" title="Spanish cuisine">Spanish cuisine</a>, such as almonds, pine nuts, and other nuts, typically ground or as paste and mixed with rice, meats, and vegetables for dishes such as rice pilaf.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Southwest_Asia">Southwest Asia</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kabukim.JPG" title="File:Kabukim.JPG">File:Kabukim.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i>Kabukim</i>, crunchy coated peanuts popular in Israel</div></div></div>
<p>Crunchy coated peanuts, called <i>kabukim</i> in Hebrew, are a popular snack in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Israel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Israel (page does not exist)">Israel</a>. <i>Kabukim</i> are commonly sold by weight at corner stores where fresh nuts and seeds are sold, though they are also available packaged. The coating typically consists of flour, salt, starch, lecithin, and sometimes sesame seeds.  The origin of the name is obscure.(It may be derived from <i>kabuk</i> which means nutshell or husk in Turkish.)  An additional variety of crunchy coated peanuts popular in Israel is "American peanuts". The coating of this variety is thinner, but harder to crack. 
</p><p>Another popular Israeli peanut snack, <a href="/wiki/Bamba_(snack)" title="Bamba (snack)">Bamba</a> puffs, is similar in shape to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cheez_Doodles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cheez Doodles (page does not exist)">Cheez Doodles</a>, but are made of corn and flavored with peanut butter.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Southeast_Asia">Southeast Asia</span></h4>
<p>Peanuts are also widely used in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asian</a> cuisine, such as <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_cuisine" title="Vietnamese cuisine">Vietnamese cuisine</a> and particularly <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cuisine_of_Indonesia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cuisine of Indonesia (page does not exist)">Indonesia</a>, where they are typically made into a spicy <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peanut_sauce&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peanut sauce (page does not exist)">sauce</a>. Peanuts originally came to Indonesia from the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>, where the legume came from Mexico in times of Spanish colonization.
</p><p>Common Indonesian peanut-based dishes include <i><a href="/wiki/Gado-gado" title="Gado-gado">gado-gado</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Pecel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pecel (page does not exist)">pecel</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Karedok" title="Karedok">karedok</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ketoprak&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ketoprak (page does not exist)">ketoprak</a></i>, all vegetable salads mixed with peanut sauce, and the peanut-based sauce for <a href="/wiki/Satay" title="Satay">satay</a>.
</p><p>In the Indian subcontinent, peanuts are known as a light snack by themselves, usually roasted and salted (sometimes with the addition of chilli powder), and often sold roasted in pod, or boiled with salt. They are also made into little dessert or sweet snack pieces by processing with refined sugar and <a href="/wiki/Jaggery" title="Jaggery">jaggery</a>. Indian cuisine uses roasted, crushed peanuts to give a crunchy body to salads; they are added whole (without pods) to leafy vegetable stews for the same reason. Another use of peanut oil as cooking oil. Most Indians use mustard, sunflower, and peanut oil for cooking. Peanuts are not native to India. They are thought to have come to India from Philippines.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="West_Africa">West Africa</span></h4>
<p>Peanuts grow well in southern <a href="/wiki/Mali" title="Mali">Mali</a> and adjacent regions of the <a href="/wiki/Ivory_Coast" title="Ivory Coast">Ivory Coast</a>, <a href="/wiki/Burkina_Faso" title="Burkina Faso">Burkina Faso</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ghana" title="Ghana">Ghana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Nigeria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Senegal" title="Senegal">Senegal</a>; peanuts are similar in both agricultural and culinary qualities to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bambara_groundnut&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bambara groundnut (page does not exist)">Bambara groundnut</a> native to the region, and West Africans have adopted the crop as a staple. Peanut sauce, prepared with onions, garlic, peanut butter/paste, and vegetables such as carrots, cabbage, and cauliflower, can be vegetarian (the peanuts supplying ample protein) or prepared with meat, usually chicken.
</p><p>Peanuts are used in the <a href="/wiki/Mali" title="Mali">Mali</a> meat stew <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Maafe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maafe (page does not exist)">maafe</a></i>. In <a href="/wiki/Ghana" title="Ghana">Ghana</a>, peanut butter is used for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peanut_soup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peanut soup (page does not exist)">peanut butter soup</a> <i>nkate nkwan</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ghanaian_cuisine_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ghanaian_cuisine-14">[14]</a></sup> Crushed peanuts may also be used for peanut candies <i>nkate cake</i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuli-kuli&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kuli-kuli (page does not exist)">kuli-kuli</a></i>, as well as other local foods such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghanaian_cuisine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ghanaian cuisine (page does not exist)"><i>oto</i></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ghanaian_cuisine_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ghanaian_cuisine-14">[14]</a></sup> Peanut butter is also an ingredient in Nigeria's "African salad".
</p><p>Peanut powder is an important ingredient in the spicy coating for <a href="/wiki/Kebab" title="Kebab">kebabs</a> in <a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Nigeria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ghana" title="Ghana">Ghana</a>.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="East_Africa">East Africa</span></h4>
<p>Peanuts are a common ingredient of several types of relishes (dishes which accompany <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nshima&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nshima (page does not exist)">nshima</a></i>) eaten by the tribes in <a href="/wiki/Malawi" title="Malawi">Malawi</a> and in the eastern part of <a href="/wiki/Zambia" title="Zambia">Zambia</a>, and these dishes are now common throughout both countries. Thick peanut butter sauces are also made in <a href="/wiki/Uganda" title="Uganda">Uganda</a> to go with rice and other starchy foods. Across East Africa, roasted peanuts (often in cones of newspaper) are a popular snack sold in the street.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="North_America">North America</span></h4>
<p>In the US, peanuts are used in candies, cakes, cookies, and other sweets. They are also enjoyed roasted and salted. <a href="/wiki/Peanut_butter" title="Peanut butter">Peanut butter</a> is one of the most popular peanut-based foods in the US, and for four hundred years, recipes for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peanut_soup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peanut soup (page does not exist)">peanut soup</a> have been present in the South, Virginia in particular.
In some southern portions of the US, peanuts are boiled for several hours until soft and moist. Peanuts are also <a href="/w/index.php?title=Deep-fried_peanuts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Deep-fried peanuts (page does not exist)">deep-fried</a>, shell and all.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Malnutrition">Malnutrition</span></h3>
<p>Peanuts are used to help fight <a href="/wiki/Malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">malnutrition</a>. <a href="/wiki/Plumpy_Nut" title="Plumpy Nut" class="mw-redirect">Plumpy Nut</a>, MANA Nutrition,<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> and Medika Mamba<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> are high-protein, high-energy and high-nutrient peanut-based pastes developed to be used as a therapeutic food to aid in <a href="/wiki/Famine_relief" title="Famine relief">famine relief</a>. The <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=UNICEF&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UNICEF (page does not exist)">UNICEF</a>, Project Peanut Butter and <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A9decins_Sans_Fronti%C3%A8res" title="Médecins Sans Frontières">Doctors Without Borders</a> have used these products to help save malnourished children in <a href="/wiki/Developing_countries" title="Developing countries" class="mw-redirect">developing countries</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_uses">Other uses</span></h3>
<p>Peanuts can be used like other legumes and grains to make a lactose-free milk-like beverage, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peanut_milk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peanut milk (page does not exist)">peanut milk</a>. Peanut plant tops are used for <a href="/wiki/Hay" title="Hay">hay</a>.
</p><p>Low-grade or culled peanuts not suitable for the edible market are used in the production of peanut oil for manufacturing.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} The protein cake (oilcake meal) residue from oil processing is used as an animal feed and as a soil fertilizer. Low-grade peanuts are also widely sold as a garden <a href="/wiki/Bird" title="Bird">bird</a> feed.
</p><p>Peanuts have a variety of industrial end uses. Paint, varnish, lubricating oil, leather dressings, furniture polish, insecticides, and <a href="/wiki/Nitroglycerin" title="Nitroglycerin">nitroglycerin</a> are made from peanut oil. Soap is made from <a href="/wiki/Saponification" title="Saponification">saponified</a> oil, and many cosmetics contain peanut oil and its derivatives. The protein portion is used in the manufacture of some textile fibers. Peanut shells are used in the manufacture of plastic, wallboard, abrasives, fuel, cellulose (used in <a href="/wiki/Rayon" title="Rayon">rayon</a> and paper) and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mucilage&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mucilage (page does not exist)">mucilage</a> (glue). <a href="/wiki/Rudolf_Diesel" title="Rudolf Diesel">Rudolf Diesel</a> ran some of the first engines that bear his name on peanut oil<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> and it is still seen as a potentially useful fuel.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Nutritional_value">Nutritional value</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Planters-Trail-Mix.jpg" title="File:Planters-Trail-Mix.jpg">File:Planters-Trail-Mix.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A pile of Planter's brand trail mix, with peanuts, cashews, M&amp;Ms, raisins, and almonds</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nutritionalvalue&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nutritionalvalue (page does not exist)">Template:Nutritionalvalue</a>
</p><p>Peanuts are rich in nutrients, providing over 30 essential nutrients and <a href="/wiki/Phytonutrient" title="Phytonutrient" class="mw-redirect">phytonutrients</a>. Peanuts are a good source of <a href="/wiki/Niacin" title="Niacin">niacin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Folate" title="Folate" class="mw-redirect">folate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fiber" title="Fiber">fiber</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vitamin_E" title="Vitamin E">vitamin E</a>, <a href="/wiki/Magnesium" title="Magnesium">magnesium</a> and <a href="/wiki/Phosphorus" title="Phosphorus">phosphorus</a>. They also are naturally free of <a href="/wiki/Trans-fat" title="Trans-fat" class="mw-redirect">trans-fats</a> and sodium, and contain about 25% protein (a higher proportion than in any true nut).<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Niacin">Niacin</span></h3>
<p>Peanuts are a good source of <a href="/wiki/Niacin" title="Niacin">niacin</a>, and thus contribute to brain health and blood flow.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Antioxidants">Antioxidants</span></h3>
<p>Recent research on peanuts has found <a href="/wiki/Antioxidants" title="Antioxidants" class="mw-redirect">antioxidants</a> and other chemicals that may provide health benefits.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> New research shows peanuts rival the antioxidant content of many fruits. Roasted peanuts rival the antioxidant content of blackberries and strawberries, and are far richer in antioxidants than carrots or beets. Research published in the journal <i>Food Chemistry</i> shows that peanuts contain high concentrations of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Polyphenol_antioxidant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Polyphenol antioxidant (page does not exist)">antioxidant polyphenols</a>, primarily a compound called <a href="/w/index.php?title=P-coumaric_acid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="P-coumaric acid (page does not exist)">p-coumaric acid</a>, and that roasting can increase peanuts' p-coumaric acid levels, boosting their overall antioxidant content by as much as 22%.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Resveratrol">Resveratrol</span></h3>
<p>Peanuts are a significant source of <a href="/wiki/Resveratrol" title="Resveratrol">resveratrol</a>, a chemical associated with but not proven to cause a reduction in risk of <a href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_disease" title="Cardiovascular disease">cardiovascular disease</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cancer" title="Cancer">cancer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Sanders2000_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sanders2000-23">[23]</a></sup>
</p><p>The average amount of resveratrol in one ounce of commonly eaten peanuts (15 whole peanut kernels) is 73 μg.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Coenzyme_Q10">Coenzyme Q10</span></h3>
<p>Peanuts are a source of <a href="/wiki/Coenzyme_Q10" title="Coenzyme Q10">coenzyme Q10</a>, as are <a href="/wiki/Oily_fish" title="Oily fish">oily fish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beef" title="Beef">beef</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soybean" title="Soybean">soybeans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spinach" title="Spinach">spinach</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Template:Visible_anchor"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Visible_anchor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Visible anchor (page does not exist)">Template:Visible anchor</a></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Allergies">Allergies</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Some people (0.6%<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> of the United States population) report that they mild to severe <a href="/wiki/Allergy" title="Allergy">allergic reactions</a> to peanut exposure; symptoms can range from watery eyes to <a href="/wiki/Anaphylaxis" title="Anaphylaxis">anaphylactic shock</a>, which can be fatal if untreated. For these individuals, eating a small amount of peanuts can cause a reaction. Because of their widespread use in prepared and packaged foods, the avoidance of peanuts is difficult. Some foods processed in facilities which also handle peanuts may carry warnings on their labels indicating such.
</p><p>A hypothesis of the development of peanut allergy has to do with the way peanuts are processed in North America versus other countries, such as Pakistan and China, where peanuts are widely eaten. According to a 2003 study, roasting peanuts, as more commonly done in North America, causes the major peanut allergen <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ara_h2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ara h2 (page does not exist)">Ara h2</a> to become a stronger inhibitor of the digestive enzyme <a href="/wiki/Trypsin" title="Trypsin">trypsin</a>, making it more resistant to digestion. Additionally, this allergen has also been shown to protect <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ara_h1&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ara h1 (page does not exist)">Ara h1</a>, another major peanut allergen, from digestion&#160;— a characteristic further enhanced by roasting.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup>
</p><p>Another hypothesis, called the <a href="/wiki/Hygiene_hypothesis" title="Hygiene hypothesis">hygiene hypothesis</a>, states that a lack of early childhood exposure to infectious agents like germs and parasites could be causing the increase of food allergies.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup>
</p><p>Recent (2008) studies comparing age of peanut introduction in Great Britain with introduction in Israel appear to show that delaying exposure to peanuts can dramatically increase the risk of developing peanut allergies.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup>
</p><p>Results from some animal studies (and limited evidence from human subjects) suggest that the dose of peanuts is an important mediator of peanut sensitisation and tolerance; low doses tend to lead to sensitisation and higher doses tend to lead to tolerance.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p><p>Peanut allergy has been associated with the use of skin preparations containing peanut oil among children, but the evidence is not regarded as conclusive.<sup id="cite_ref-lack_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lack-32">[32]</a></sup> Peanut allergies have also been associated with family history and intake of soy products.<sup id="cite_ref-lack_32-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lack-32">[32]</a></sup>
</p><p>Though the allergy can last a lifetime, another 2003 study indicates that 23.3% of children will outgrow a peanut allergy.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some <a href="/wiki/School_district" title="School district">school districts</a> in the United States have banned peanuts.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> There are experimental techniques which appear to have desensitized some allergic individuals.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> The most popular technique, oral immunotherapy, works to create desensitization in those allergic by feeding them small amounts of peanuts until their body becomes desensitized. Some progress is possibly being made in the UK, where researchers at Cambridge are studying the effectiveness of the desensitization technique.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p><p>Research indicates that refined peanut oil will not cause allergic reactions in most people with peanut allergies.<sup id="cite_ref-The_anaphylaxis_campaign_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_anaphylaxis_campaign-39">[39]</a></sup> However, crude (unrefined) peanut oils are strongly flavoured, and have been shown to contain protein, which may cause allergic reactions.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> In a randomized, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Double-blind&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Double-blind (page does not exist)">double-blind</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crossover_study&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crossover study (page does not exist)">crossover study</a>, 60 people with proven peanut allergy were challenged with both crude peanut oil and refined peanut oil. The authors conclude, "Crude peanut oil caused allergic reactions in 10% of allergic subjects studied and should continue to be avoided." They also state, "Refined peanut oil does not seem to pose a risk to most people with peanut allergy." However, they point out that refined peanut oil can still pose a risk to peanut-allergic individuals if oil that has previously been used to cook foods containing peanuts is reused.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Contamination_with_aflatoxin">Contamination with aflatoxin</span></h3>
<p>Peanuts may be contaminated with the <a href="/wiki/Mold" title="Mold">mold</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Aspergillus_flavus" title="Aspergillus flavus">Aspergillus flavus</a></i> which produces a <a href="/wiki/Carcinogenic" title="Carcinogenic" class="mw-redirect">carcinogenic</a> substance called <a href="/wiki/Aflatoxin#Pathology" title="Aflatoxin">aflatoxin</a>. Lower quality specimens, particularly where <a href="/wiki/Mold" title="Mold">mold</a> is evident, are more likely to be contaminated.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Agriculture" title="United States Department of Agriculture">United States Department of Agriculture</a> (USDA) tests every truckload of raw peanuts for aflatoxin; any containing aflatoxin levels of more than 15 parts per billion are destroyed. The peanut industry has manufacturing steps in place to ensure all peanuts are inspected for aflatoxin.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> Peanuts are also processed at a high temperature to ensure any microorganisms are killed.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cardiovascular_disease">Cardiovascular disease</span></h3>
<p>A 1974 study suggested that consuming large amounts of peanut oil can cause clogging of the arteries. Robert Wissler of the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Chicago" title="University of Chicago">University of Chicago</a> reported that diets high in peanut oil, when combined with high dietary <a href="/wiki/Cholesterol" title="Cholesterol">cholesterol</a> intake, clogged the arteries of <a href="/wiki/Rhesus_monkey" title="Rhesus monkey" class="mw-redirect">Rhesus monkeys</a> more than <a href="/wiki/Butterfat" title="Butterfat">butterfat</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> However, subsequent work has cast serious doubt on those findings. In the Rhesus study, monkeys were being fed 20 times higher than normal dietary quantities of cholesterol in addition to peanut oil. When a similar study was performed without abnormal doses of cholesterol, no such effect was seen.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> Peanut oil has been found to lower <a href="/wiki/LDL_cholesterol" title="LDL cholesterol" class="mw-redirect">LDL cholesterol</a> without reducing <a href="/wiki/HDL_cholesterol" title="HDL cholesterol" class="mw-redirect">HDL cholesterol</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="U.S._Department_of_Agriculture_.28USDA.29_program">U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) program</span></h2>
<p><a href="/wiki/George_Washington_Carver" title="George Washington Carver">George Washington Carver</a> is often credited with inventing 300 different uses for peanuts<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> (which, contrary to popular belief, did not include <a href="/wiki/Peanut_butter" title="Peanut butter">peanut butter</a> but did include salted peanuts). Carver was one of many USDA researchers<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> who encouraged <a href="/wiki/Cotton" title="Cotton">cotton</a> farmers in the South to grow peanuts instead of, or in addition to, cotton, because cotton had depleted so much nitrogen from the soil, and one of the peanut's properties as a legume is to put nitrogen back into the soil (a process known as <a href="/wiki/Nitrogen_fixation" title="Nitrogen fixation">nitrogen fixation</a>). Rising demand for peanuts in the early 20th century was due to a shortage of plant oils during World War I and the growing popularity of peanut butter, roasted peanuts and peanut candies.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> Peanut products originating around the early 20th century include many brands still sold today such as <a href="/wiki/Cracker_Jack" title="Cracker Jack">Cracker Jack</a> (1893), <a href="/wiki/Planters" title="Planters">Planters</a> peanuts (1906), <a href="/wiki/Oh_Henry!" title="Oh Henry!">Oh Henry!</a> candy bar (1920), <a href="/wiki/Baby_Ruth" title="Baby Ruth">Baby Ruth</a> candy bar (1920), <a href="/wiki/Butterfinger" title="Butterfinger">Butterfinger</a> candy bar (1923), <a href="/wiki/Mr._Goodbar" title="Mr. Goodbar">Mr. Goodbar</a> candy bar (1925), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reese%27s_Peanut_Butter_Cup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reese's Peanut Butter Cup (page does not exist)">Reese's Peanut Butter Cup</a> (1925), and <a href="/wiki/Peter_Pan_(peanut_butter)" title="Peter Pan (peanut butter)">Peter Pan (peanut butter)</a> (1928).
</p><p>Peanuts were designated by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Congress_of_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Congress of the United States (page does not exist)">U.S. Congress</a> to be one of America's basic crops. To protect domestic industry by keeping prices artificially high, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Agriculture" title="United States Department of Agriculture">United States Department of Agriculture</a> (USDA) aids peanut farmers through commodity programs.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} In the 2008 Farm Bill, the marketing quota for peanuts was eliminated and the Price Support Program was switched to a Direct and Counter-Cyclical Payment Program. Direct and counter-cyclical payments provide benefits to producers with eligible historical production of peanuts whenever the effective price is less than the targeted price.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Trade">Trade</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vendeuse_d%27arachides.jpg" title="File:Vendeuse d'arachides.jpg">File:Vendeuse d'arachides.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Peanut seller in <a href="/wiki/Ouagadougou" title="Ouagadougou">Ouagadougou</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Jiangxia-peanuts-9707.jpg" title="File:Jiangxia-peanuts-9707.jpg">File:Jiangxia-peanuts-9707.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Peanut buying station in rural <a href="/wiki/Wuhan" title="Wuhan">Wuhan</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Although <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> and <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> are the world's largest producers of peanuts, they account for a small part of international trade because most of their production is consumed domestically as <a href="/wiki/Peanut_oil" title="Peanut oil">peanut oil</a>. Exports of peanuts from India and China are equivalent to less than 4% of world trade.  The major producers/exporters of peanuts are the United States, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Argentina (page does not exist)">Argentina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sudan" title="Sudan">Sudan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Senegal" title="Senegal">Senegal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>. These five countries account for 71% of total world exports. In recent years,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Vague&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Vague (page does not exist)">Template:Vague</a> the United States has been the leading exporter of peanuts.
</p><p>The major peanut importers are the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> (EU), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Canada&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Canada (page does not exist)">Canada</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>. These three areas account for 78% of the world's imports.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} Most of Canada's peanut butter is processed from Chinese peanuts.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}  Two thirds of U.S. imports are roasted, unshelled peanuts. The major suppliers are <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malaysia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Malaysia (page does not exist)">Malaysia</a>, Hong Kong, <a href="/wiki/Mainland_China" title="Mainland China">Mainland China</a>, and Canada.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}  The principal suppliers of shelled peanut imports are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Argentina (page does not exist)">Argentina</a> and Canada. Imports of peanut butter from Argentina are in the form of a paste and must be further processed. Other minor suppliers of peanut butter include <a href="/wiki/Malawi" title="Malawi">Malawi</a>, China, India, and <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>.
</p><p>The European Union is the largest consuming region in the world that does not produce peanuts. All of its consumption is supplied by imports. Consumption of peanuts in the EU is primarily as food, mostly as roasted-in-shell peanuts and as shelled peanuts used in confectionery and bakery products.
</p><p>The average annual U.S. imports of peanuts are less than 0.5% of U.S. consumption.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Georgia_(U.S._state)" title="Georgia (U.S. state)">Georgia</a> is the leading peanut producing state in the U.S., followed by <a href="/wiki/Texas" title="Texas">Texas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alabama" title="Alabama">Alabama</a>, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> About half of all peanuts produced in the United States are grown within a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> radius of <a href="/wiki/Dothan,_Alabama" title="Dothan, Alabama">Dothan, Alabama</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> Dothan is home to the National Peanut Festival established in 1938 and held each fall to honor peanut growers and celebrate the harvest.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ninety percent of India's production is processed into peanut oil. Only a nominal amount of hand-picked select-grade peanuts are exported. India prohibits the importation of all oil seeds,{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} including peanuts.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=African_Groundnut_Council&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="African Groundnut Council (page does not exist)">African Groundnut Council</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Tanganyika_groundnut_scheme" title="Tanganyika groundnut scheme">Tanganyika groundnut scheme</a>, a spectacular failure started in 1951
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=BBCH-scale_(peanut)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BBCH-scale (peanut) (page does not exist)">BBCH-scale (peanut)</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Beer_Nuts" title="Beer Nuts">Beer Nuts</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/List_of_edible_seeds" title="List of edible seeds">List of edible seeds</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Universal_Nut_Sheller&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Universal Nut Sheller (page does not exist)">Universal Nut Sheller</a>
</li>
</ul>

</li>

</li>
</ul>
